Expectation1: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation1: They notice the need to use protective equipment and follow hygiene steps more consistently.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I stood in the polling station, the faint scent of disinfectant clinging to my clothes from my morning shift. As a housekeeping cleaner, I’d spent hours scrubbing surfaces, always careful to wear gloves, mask, and follow every hygiene protocol. My supervisor’s words echoed in my mind: “Never touch anything without protection. Safety first, always.” Now, as a voter, I held my ballot envelope, noticing the ink had smudged. The poll worker smiled and handed it back. “Could you please re-sign this? We want to make sure your vote counts.” I glanced at the communal pen, lying bare on the table, touched by dozens of hands. My instincts screamed at me to ask for sanitizer, to put on gloves, to refuse. But the poll worker’s expectant gaze and the line of people behind me pressed in. I felt torn—my duty to protect myself and others from germs clashing with my responsibility to follow the voting process. My heart pounded as I hesitated, caught between the rules of my job and the demands of my civic duty, unsure which expectation I should honor in this moment.
